summary: This document is an email chain between a SigNet Technologies program manager and a DOJ communication technician regarding a discrepancy in camera models ordered for installation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The issue involves cameras not being on the approved hardware list for the Bureau of Prisons (BOP).

persons.name: Program Manager FBOP Contracts SigNet Technologies
persons.context: SigNet Technologies employee responding to a camera discrepancy issue at MCC New York, recommending opening a ticket to add cameras to the approved list.

persons.name: Communication Technician US Department of Justice MCC-New York
persons.context: DOJ employee at MCC New York who identified a discrepancy between proposed and received camera models for installation.

connections.person1: Program Manager FBOP Contracts SigNet Technologies
connections.person2: Communication Technician US Department of Justice MCC-New York
connections.description: Correspondence regarding a procurement and installation issue for security cameras at MCC New York, indicating a vendor-client or contractor relationship.

events.title: Camera Discrepancy Correspondence
events.description: Email exchange regarding a discrepancy between proposed and received camera models for installation at MCC New York, with concerns about cameras not being on the BOP approved hardware list.
personsInvolved: Program Manager FBOP Contracts SigNet Technologies
Communication Technician US Department of Justice MCC-New York

locations: MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center), 150 Park Row, New York, NY
SigNet Technologies, 12300 Kiln Ct Suite E, Beltsville, MD 20705
keyFacts: The correspondence is dated September 5, 2019, which is shortly after Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody at MCC New York on August 10, 2019.
The email discusses installing security cameras at MCC New York, highlighting ongoing facility upgrades or maintenance.
There is a discrepancy between proposed camera models (Won IC)M62WR-B9) and received models (Vicon V9420-W312MIR), with the latter not on the BOP approved hardware list.
The SigNet Technologies manager notes that 90% of cameras on the approved list are EOL (End of Life), indicating potential systemic issues with equipment procurement.
The document shows routine administrative communication between a DOJ facility and a technology contractor, unrelated to specific Epstein case events but contextual to the facility where he died.
